elements.content: Non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries have aroused considerable attention because of their ultrahigh theoretical energy density, but they are severely hindered by slow cathode reaction kinetics and large overvoltages, which are closely associated with the discharge product of Li2O2. Herein, hexagonal conductive metal–organic framework nanowire arrays of nickel-hexaiminotriphenylene (Ni-HTP) with quadrilateral Ni-N4 units are synthesized to incorporate Ru atoms into its skeleton for NiRu-HTP. The atomically dispersed Ru-N4 sites manifest strong adsorption for the LiO2 intermediate owing to its tunable d-band center, leading to its high local concentration around NiRu-HTP. This favors the formation of film-like Li2O2 on NiRu-HTP with promoted electron transfer and ion diffusion across the cathode-electrolyte interface, facilitating its reversible decomposition during charge. These allow the Li–O2 battery with NiRu-HTP to deliver a remarkably reduced charge/discharge polarization of 0.76 V and excellent cyclability. This work will enrich the design philosophy of electrocatalysts for regulation of kinetic behaviors of oxygen redox.

elements.content: Non-aqueous Li–O2 batteries promise ultrahigh theoretical specific capacity (∼3600 W h kg–1) with the reversible oxygen redox reactions of 2Li + O2 ↔ Li2O2 (E 0 = 2.96 V). However, their deployment is plagued by large overvoltages and inferior energy efficiencies, which are mainly ascribed to the high kinetic barriers for oxygen reduction/evolution reactions (ORR/OER) at cathodes upon discharging and charging, respectively. The irregular deposition of large insulating Li2O2 toroids as the discharge product readily causes high-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact and hence large overvoltages during cycles, leading to declining capacities and poor stability for Li–O2 batteries. Modulation of the growth behavior and morphology of Li2O2 remains quite challenging and is pivotal for the battery performance. This demands rational design of cathode catalysts to promote oxygen electrocatalysis with tunable Li2O2 formation and oxidation for Li–O2 batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Non-aqueous Li-O2 batteries promise ultrahigh theoretical specific capacity (~3600 W h kg-1) with the reversible oxygen redox reactions of 2Li + O2 ↔ Li2O2 (E 0 = 2.96 V). However, their deployment is plagued by large overvoltages and inferior energy efficiencies, which are mainly ascribed to the high kinetic barriers for oxygen reduction/evolution reactions (ORR/OER) at cathodes upon discharging and charging, respectively. The irregular deposition of large insulating Li2O2 toroids as the discharge product readily causes high-impedance Li2O2/cathode contact and hence large overvoltages during cycles, leading to declining capacities and poor stability for Li-O2 batteries. Modulation of the growth behavior and morphology of Li2O2 remains quite challenging and is pivotal for the battery performance. This demands rational design of cathode catalysts to promote oxygen electrocatalysis with tunable Li2O2 formation and oxidation for Li-O2 batteries.

elements.content: The growth kinetics and morphology of Li2O2 are mainly related to the adsorption on the surface or solvation into electrolytes of the LiO2 intermediate, which are dominated by the discharge current density, electrolyte, and cathode catalyst. This inspires efforts on surface/electronic engineering of cathode catalysts to tune the cathode reaction pathways and eventually alter the morphologies. The RuO2, Co9S8, and facet-selected MnO2 catalysts presented strong affinity with the LiO2 intermediate to induce formation of Li2O2 films for improved charge kinetics. Nevertheless, their low catalytic selectivity results in parasitic reactions, in addition to oxygen redox, and charge overvoltages of over 1.0 V, and inferior round-trip efficiency. The correlation of reaction pathways with catalytic active sites remains ambiguous. Intriguingly, conductive metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) were attempted for oxygen electrocatalysis owing to the uniformly dispersed active centers, open porous structures, and adjustable pore sizes. Their well-defined structures benefit the investigation of atomic-level structure–activity relationship. The electronic structure of MOFs can be modulated with the selectively changed metal nodes. Thereby, it is highly promising to develop conductive MOF-based catalysts to regulate the reaction pathways and modulate the deposition morphology of Li2O2 for Li–O2 batteries.

elements.content: Herein, the conductive bimetallic MOF nanowire arrays of NiRu-HTP are synthesized via an ion-exchange method to serve as a bifunctional cathode catalyst with accelerated reaction kinetics for Li–O2 batteries. The atomically dispersed Ru-N4 sites in NiRu-HTP exhibit high adsorption capability of the LiO2 intermediate to increase its local concentration. This regulates a uniform film-like Li2O2 product among NiRu-HTP nanowires to accelerate the electron transfer and ion diffusion across the cathode-electrolyte interface. These manifest the Li–O2 battery with enhanced kinetics for small polarizations, good rate performance, and superior reversibility. This work will provide new insights into MOF-based electrocatalyst design to regulate the cathode reaction pathways for the high-performance Li–O2 battery and beyond.

elements.content: The well-aligned nanowire arrays of Ni-HTP were grown directly on carbon paper as electrodes through the coordination of Ni2+ with 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene (HTP) in a hydrothermal reaction (Figure S1). NiRu-HTP was prepared by partially replacing Ni sites with Ru via an ion-exchange method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP electrodes are shown in a and S2, respectively. The directional nanoarrays densely surround the carbon fibers of about 30 nm in diameter and ∼1 μm in length, which induce the hierarchical porous structure to benefit electron transfer, gas diffusion, and exposure of catalytic active sites. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP nanowires manifest high crystallinity and interplanar spacing of 1.8 nm, as displayed in b and S3. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurement of NiRu-HTP indicates that the contents of Ru and Ni are 37 and 63%, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP

The well-aligned nanowire arrays of Ni-HTP were grown directly on carbon paper as electrodes through the coordination of Ni2+ with 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene (HTP) in a hydrothermal reaction (Figure S1). NiRu-HTP was prepared by partially replacing Ni sites with Ru via an ion-exchange method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP electrodes are shown in a and S2, respectively. The directional nanoarrays densely surround the carbon fibers of about 30 nm in diameter and ~1 μm in length, which induce the hierarchical porous structure to benefit electron transfer, gas diffusion, and exposure of catalytic active sites. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP nanowires manifest high crystallinity and interplanar spacing of 1.8 nm, as displayed in b and S3. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurement of NiRu-HTP indicates that the contents of Ru and Ni are 37 and 63%, respectively.

(g) Ni K-edge XANES spectra and (h) transformed EXAFS spectra at the Ni K-edge of NiRu-HTP, Ni-HTP, and NiO. (i) Ru K-edge XANES spectra, (j) transformed EXAFS spectra at the Ru K-edge, and (k) WT for the k3-weighted EXAFS signal of NiRu-HTP, Ni-HTP, and Ru foil.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP in c and S4a suggest their high crystalline features. Pawley refinements were conducted to simulate their crystal structures, which reveal that they can be assigned to the hexagonal structure. The prominent peaks at 4.7, 9.4, 12.4, and 16.5° are corresponding to the (001), (002), (210), and (004) facets, respectively, indicating the long-range order within the ab plane. Their comprehensive crystallographic information is depicted in Table S1, and their main structure variations are the lattice constants and unit cell volume. The Ni or Ru atoms are coordinated with the tritopic HTP linkers to form hexagonal units in Ni-HTP or NiRu-HTP with the layered graphene-like honeycomb structure, as depicted in d and S4b. The enlarged HRTEM image of NiRu-HTP perpendicular to the c-axis in e presents an ordered honeycomb arrangement of hexagonal pores of 2.0 nm along the [001] direction, which is consistent with the simulated structure of NiRu-HTP. The molecular structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP were disclosed in Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of Figure S5. The three peaks at 1273, 1513, and 1619 cm–1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C–C, C–N, and CN bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively. The stretching vibration peak of C–N upshifts from 1502 cm–1 (H–N–C, HTP) to 1513 cm–1 (Ru/Ni–N–C) due to the formation of Ni–N or Ru–N bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, along with the peak disappearance of Ar-NH2 at 3275 cm–1.

elements.content: The chemical states of elements in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Ru 3p spectrum of NiRu-HTP in Figure S6a indicates the successful incorporation of Ru atoms. It shows two characteristic peaks of Ru 3p1/2 and Ru 3p3/2 at 484.9 and 462.8 eV, respectively. The Ni 2p spectra of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP exhibit two peaks at 873.1 and 855.9 eV (Figure S6b) for respective Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2, implying the presence of Ni2+. Both of their N 1s spectra in f can be assigned to two distinct peaks, corresponding to C–N and Ni–N x moieties, respectively. The positive shift of the peaks in the N 1s spectrum of NiRu-HTP is ascribed to the coordination effect of Ru with N. The uniform distribution of Ni and Ru in NiRu-HTP is confirmed by XPS with Ar+ etching at different depths of 0, 5, 10, and 15 nm, as shown in Figure S7.

elements.content: X-ray absorption spectroscopy is employed to study the coordination of Ni and Ru in Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP. g displays the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Ni K-edge in NiO, Ni-HTP, and NiRu-HTP. The edge positions of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are approaching that of NiO, indicating that the Ni species are positively charged with the valence state of +2, in consistence with XPS (Figure S6b). The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum of Ni-HTP displays its characteristic peak at 1.3 Å, and it is assigned to the Ni–N bond (h). The EXAFS fitting indicates the average coordination number of 4 on Ni within Ni-HTP (Figure S8), corresponding to the Ni-N4 units, in line with the resolved crystal structure in Figure S4. The XANES spectra of Ru K-edge in i suggest that the edge position of NiRu-HTP is located between Ru foil and RuO2, revealing that Ru exists with the valence state between 0 and +4. The Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectrum of NiRu-HTP in j exhibits a characteristic peak of 1.47 Å for the Ru–N bond, and its fitting indicates an average coordination number of 4 for Ru–N in Figure S8. In comparison with Ru foil and RuO2, no characteristic peaks of Ru–Ru bonds in NiRu-HTP can be observed and suggest the atomically dispersed Ru sites. The wavelet transform (WT) analyses are further performed for the Ru K-edge XANES spectra of NiRu-HTP (k). It displays a WT intensity maximum at ≈5.0 Å–1 for the planar Ru–N coordination, which is obviously different from RuO2 and Ru–Ru bonds at 10.5 Å–1 in Ru foil. This verifies the atomic dispersion of Ru-N4 in NiRu-HTP.

elements.content: The electronic structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are uncovered by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. According to the total density of state (TDOS) analyses in a,b, the continuous electron occupation of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP near the Fermi level (E f) suggests that both possess a high electrical conductivity. The obviously larger electron density of NiRu-HTP near E f than that of Ni-HTP implies a higher electrical conductivity, which is confirmed by the conductivity measurements in Figure S9. In addition, the fully symmetric electron state densities of Ni-HTP indicate that the Ni atoms are of low spin with no single electron. In NiRu-HTP, the electron state densities near E f are asymmetric and spin-polarized, which is attributed to the plentiful single electrons on Ru atoms, contributing to the gas adsorption and activation. Generally, the d-orbital energy level center (E d) is considered as a good descriptor to evaluate the adsorbate-metal interaction and electrocatalytic activity. The integration of TDOS of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP yields the E d of −1.82 and −1.43 eV for Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP, respectively. The higher E d of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP suggests the enhanced O2 adsorption and higher oxygen reduction activity. The valence band maxima (E VB) of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are estimated to be ca. −0.32 and 0.07 eV, respectively (Figure S10). Since the valence electrons are approaching E f and mainly contribute to the d states, it allows the distinctly higher d-orbital energy level of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP, in accordance with the abovementioned TDOS analyses.

Electronic Structure of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP

The electronic structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are uncovered by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. According to the total density of state (TDOS) analyses in a,b, the continuous electron occupation of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP near the Fermi level (E f) suggests that both possess a high electrical conductivity. The obviously larger electron density of NiRu-HTP near E f than that of Ni-HTP implies a higher electrical conductivity, which is confirmed by the conductivity measurements in Figure S9. In addition, the fully symmetric electron state densities of Ni-HTP indicate that the Ni atoms are of low spin with no single electron. In NiRu-HTP, the electron state densities near E f are asymmetric and spin-polarized, which is attributed to the plentiful single electrons on Ru atoms, contributing to the gas adsorption and activation. Generally, the d-orbital energy level center (E d) is considered as a good descriptor to evaluate the adsorbate-metal interaction and electrocatalytic activity. The integration of TDOS of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP yields the E d of -1.82 and -1.43 eV for Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP, respectively. The higher E d of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP suggests the enhanced O2 adsorption and higher oxygen reduction activity. The valence band maxima (E VB) of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are estimated to be ca. -0.32 and 0.07 eV, respectively (Figure S10). Since the valence electrons are approaching E f and mainly contribute to the d states, it allows the distinctly higher d-orbital energy level of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP, in accordance with the abovementioned TDOS analyses.

(e,f) Differential charge densities of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP after O2 adsorption with the isosurface value of 0.003 e bohr–3. Cyan and yellow areas correspond to the respective charge depletion and accumulation.

(e,f) Differential charge densities of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP after O2 adsorption with the isosurface value of 0.003 e bohr-3. elements.content: PDOS calculations are performed to investigate the interplay between Ni-HTP/NiRu-HTP and O2 molecules, as plotted in c,d. The electronic interaction is regarded as the coupling of molecular orbitals of O2 with d orbitals of metal nodes, giving rise to the orbital splitting to form the separated bonding and antibonding orbitals in Figure S11. The bonding states locate far below the E f and are generally fully filled, while the electron filling of antibonding states is decided by the position of d-orbitals relative to E f and contributes to the bonding strength. Obviously, NiRu-HTP manifests a significantly higher E d and larger hybridization degree with the 2p orbitals of O2 than Ni-HTP, which implies its higher bonding strength with O2. Specifically, at the Ni-N4 site, the d xz and d yz orbitals of Ni are overlapped with π orbitals of O2 to generate the (d xz /d yz -π)* orbitals, as shown in c. For the Ru-N4 site, the d z 2 and d xz orbitals of the Ru site are coupled with the σ and π orbitals of O2 to constitute the respective ( d z 2 -σ)* and (d xz -π)* orbitals, as plotted in d. As compared with the (d xz /d yz -π)* in Ni-HTP, the ( d z 2 -σ)* and (d xz -π)* in NiRu-HTP displays a lower electron occupancy and higher energy level, which suggest the enhanced O2 adsorption and boosted Ru–O2 interaction. The O2-enrichment capabilities of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are confirmed by low-pressure O2 adsorption at 298.25 K (Figure S12). Their O2 uptake linearly rises as a function of pressure, and NiRu-HTP exhibits an O2 adsorption of 7.02 cm–3 g–1 under an ambient atmosphere, obviously outperforming Ni-HTP (3.33 cm–3 g–1), suggesting the stronger O2 adsorption on NiRu-HTP.

elements.content: e,f shows the differential charge density of O2 adsorption on Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP. The higher adsorption energy of O2 on NiRu-HTP (−1.47 eV) than that of Ni-HTP (0.28 eV) indicates its stronger affinity with O2. The Ru–O and Ni–O bond lengths after O2 adsorption are ca. 1.80 and 2.98 Å, respectively, suggesting the chemisorption and physical adsorption of O2 on NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively. Bader charge analyses reveal that 0.47 e– transfers from NiRu-HTP to O2 against 0.22 e– from Ni-HTP to O2, which suggest the enhanced electron transfer and higher catalytic activity on NiRu-HTP. After the injection of valence electrons into molecular orbitals of O2, the O–O bonding is weakened to manifest the elongated bond length of 1.30 and 1.27 Å for NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively, indicating the more efficient O2 activation on NiRu-HTP.

elements.content: a displays the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with voltages ranging from 2.0 to 4.0 V. In the cathodic sweep, they present successive reduction peaks, indicating the continuous generation of LiO2 and Li2O2. During the reverse sweep, two distinct oxidation peaks are ascribed to the stepwise oxidation of Li2O2 with the LiO2 intermediate. Compared with Ni-HTP, NiRu-HTP shows the larger current density, as well as larger ORR onset potential (∼2.76 V) and smaller OER onset potential (∼2.98 V), suggesting its better electrocatalytic activity. The electrochemical performance of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes in b is examined at 500 mA g–1. The total polarizations during charge/discharge of Ni-HTP are 3.98/2.67 V with a low energy efficiency of 67.1%. In contrast, NiRu-HTP presents the discharge and charge voltages of 2.74 and 3.62 V, respectively, suggesting an overvoltage of 0.88 V and energy efficiency of 75.7%. c shows the charge/discharge curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with a limited voltage of 2.20 V. NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP cathodes show the respective ultrahigh capacities of 15,080 and 18,280 mA h g–1, which are attributed to their hierarchically porous structures and superior electrical conductivity. Meanwhile, NiRu-HTP displays a much smaller charge/discharge polarization (∼1.20 V) than Ni-HTP, indicating the enhanced ORR and OER kinetics on NiRu-HTP for the Li2O2 formation and decomposition.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Performance and Mechanistic Analyses

 a displays the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with voltages ranging from 2.0 to 4.0 V. In the cathodic sweep, they present successive reduction peaks, indicating the continuous generation of LiO2 and Li2O2. During the reverse sweep, two distinct oxidation peaks are ascribed to the stepwise oxidation of Li2O2 with the LiO2 intermediate. Compared with Ni-HTP, NiRu-HTP shows the larger current density, as well as larger ORR onset potential (~2.76 V) and smaller OER onset potential (~2.98 V), suggesting its better electrocatalytic activity. The electrochemical performance of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes in b is examined at 500 mA g-1. The total polarizations during charge/discharge of Ni-HTP are 3.98/2.67 V with a low energy efficiency of 67.1%. In contrast, NiRu-HTP presents the discharge and charge voltages of 2.74 and 3.62 V, respectively, suggesting an overvoltage of 0.88 V and energy efficiency of 75.7%. c shows the charge/discharge curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with a limited voltage of 2.20 V. NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP cathodes show the respective ultrahigh capacities of 15,080 and 18,280 mA h g-1, which are attributed to their hierarchically porous structures and superior electrical conductivity. Meanwhile, NiRu-HTP displays a much smaller charge/discharge polarization (~1.20 V) than Ni-HTP, indicating the enhanced ORR and OER kinetics on NiRu-HTP for the Li2O2 formation and decomposition.

elements.content: d,e depicts the rate capability of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes at the different current densities. The charge/discharge overvoltages are 0.76, 0.90, and 1.03 V for the NiRu-HTP cathode at 200, 500, and 1000 mA g–1, respectively. This is in contrast to the rapidly increased voltage hysterisis of Ni-HTP at the identical testing condition in e. f shows the plot of the overvoltages of NiRu-HTP and the other MOF-based cathodes at 200 mA g–1. Notably, NiRu-HTP presents the lowest overvoltage and is approaching the benchmarking RuO2. Their cycling performance is examined at 500 mA g–1 and presented in g. NiRu-HTP can sustain for 200 cycles with no obvious voltage drops, suggesting excellent cycling stability, while Ni-HTP operates for 150 cycles, followed by rapid voltage increase to 4.2 V. NiRu-HTP has no redox activity as indicated in Figure S13, and its superior electrochemical performance is favored by the superior catalytic activity for ORR and OER and high electrical conductivity.

elements.content: The discharge product on Ni-HTP is recognized as crystalline Li2O2 by XRD measurement (PDF 73-1640), as depicted in a. In contrast, very weak diffraction peaks of Li2O2 are observed on the discharged NiRu-HTP under the same condition, implying poor crystallization. Raman spectra (b) verify the discharge product Li2O2 on NiRu-HTP, in which the typical peak at 800 cm–1 belongs to the O–O bond vibration. It is also evidenced by the Li 1s peak located at 55.1 eV in the XPS spectrum of discharged NiRu-HTP in c. Upon the reverse charge, all the characteristic Raman band, XPS spectrum, and XRD peak of Li2O2 on the discharged NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP reversibly disappear, as shown in a–c and S14, indicating excellent reversibility and which is in agreement with the battery performance in .

elements.content: The O2 consumption and generation during discharge and charge of NiRu-HTP are quantitatively analyzed with differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS). The charge-to-O2 ratios are 2.06 and 2.03 e–/O2 during discharge and charge in Figure S15, respectively, suggesting an approximate two-electron reaction for Li2O2 formation and decomposition without detectable CO2. The discharged and charged NiRu-HTP after 50 cycles were analyzed by XPS, as shown in Figure S16, revealing the main discharge product of Li2O2 with minor Li2CO3. Simultaneously, the cycled NiRu-HTP is confirmed to be highly stable with XPS and FTIR analyses in Figures S17 and S18, respectively, in agreement with no metal loss of Ni or Ru during cycles as revealed by ICP-MS of the separators extracted from Li–O2 batteries (Table S3).

elements.content: The evolution of morphologies of the discharge products on Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP is recorded with SEM at varied cutoff capacities in d,e and S19. At the capacity of 1 A h g–1, toroidal Li2O2 particulates of ca. 0.5 μm in size are grown in the interspace of Ni-HTP nanowire arrays. As the capacity changes to 2 and 5 A h g–1, more toroidal Li2O2 is accumulated to fully cover the electrode surface of Ni-HTP. However, on NiRu-HTP, Li2O2 presents a unique film-like morphology among the nanowires with a limited capacity of 1 A h g–1. When the capacity increases to 2 and 5 A h g–1, the film-like Li2O2 is gradually thickened to fill the void interspace of NiRu-HTP nanowire arrays. A similar morphology is well retained at the fully discharged NiRu-HTP in Figure S20. This contributes to the facile charge transfer and ion diffusion across the NiRu-HTP cathode/electrolyte interface, as verified by EIS in Figure S21 and Table S4, which favors the oxidative decomposition of Li2O2 in Figure S22 with reduced overvoltages. These suggest tunable kinetic behaviors of Li2O2 formation and oxidation, consistent with the battery performance in .

elements.content: The rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) is applied for detection of the oxygen redox intermediates on NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP in a. O2 is first reduced at the disk electrode, and the soluble LiO2 is then oxidized at the ring electrode, in which the ring current is proportional to the dissolved LiO2. NiRu-HTP shows the higher disk and onset currents than Ni-HTP, meaning its higher electrocatalytic activity. However, its ring currents are much lower than those of Ni-HTP, suggesting low concentration of LiO2 in the electrolyte. This can be ascribed to the stronger adsorption of LiO2 on NiRu-HTP than on Ni-HTP, as confirmed by the calculated adsorption energy of −2.34 eV on NiRu-HTP against −1.22 eV on Ni-HTP in Figure S23. The electrolytes in Li–O2 batteries with NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are extracted with dimethyl sulfoxide after discharge and charge for electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy in b and S24. Their pronounced EPR signals suggest the dissolution of LiO2 intermediate into electrolytes, in accordance with the RRDE tests in a. These manifest that the ORR on both NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP proceeds via a solution-mediated pathway, but their various adsorption capabilities dictate the formation of toroidal or film-like Li2O2.

elements.content: DFT calculations are exerted to elucidate the oxygen redox chemistry upon discharging. c and S25 depict the free energy profiles of O2 reduction on NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with their optimized geometrical structures. The entire steps of Li2O2 formation on NiRu-HTP are exothermal and spontaneous, while the O2 adsorption on Ni-HTP is endothermic with activation energy, 0.28 eV. The rate-determining step of ORR is the transformation of LiO2 to Li2O2 on NiRu-HTP and the O2 adsorption on Ni-HTP. Specifically, O2 is preferentially adsorbed on Ru sites of NiRu-HTP and then combines with Li+ for LiO2, which is finally transformed to Li2O2. The proposed reaction mechanisms on NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are illustrated in d. Upon discharging, O2 molecules are captured at the atomically dispersed Ru-N4 sites and accept electrons for LiO2. The strong affinity between the LiO2 and Ru-N4 sites in NiRu-HTP induces its accumulation around the nanowire arrays and hence high local concentration. The strong adsorption and massive nucleation sites promote dense film-like Li2O2, which is beneficial for the facile charge transfer and ion diffusion across the NiRu-HTP cathode-electrolyte interface. However, due to the poor adsorption capability of LiO2 on Ni-HTP, it tends to be dissolved in electrolytes and disproportionates for large Li2O2 toroids. The oxidation of large Li2O2 particulates suffers from high overvoltages because the toroidal particles are remote from the catalytic active surface. The formation pathways and morphologies of Li2O2 are related to the surface chemistry of cathode catalysts and dictate the interfacial reaction kinetics and battery performance.

elements.content: A conductive bimetallic MOF of NiRu-HTP is successfully prepared via ion-exchange to act as an efficient catalyst to promote oxygen redox kinetics of Li–O2 batteries. Upon discharging, O2 is preferentially chemisorbed on atomically dispersed Ru-N4 sites in NiRu-HTP, and the d z 2 and d xz orbitals of Ru separately donate electrons to σ and π orbitals of O2 for its reduction to LiO2, subsequently converted into the discharge product Li2O2. Reversely, it is delithiated to LiO2 and further oxidized to O2 and Li+. NiRu-HTP displays an upshifted E d and larger adsorption strength toward LiO2 to promote the formation of film-like Li2O2 against toroid-like Li2O2 on Ni-HTP. This conduces to the charge transfer and ion diffusion across the NiRu-HTP cathode-electrolyte interface to accelerate the charge kinetics. The Li–O2 battery with NiRu-HTP displays a reduced charge/discharge polarization of 0.76 V and operates for 200 cycles without performance decay. This work regulating oxygen redox via local atomic engineering of MOFs for enhanced kinetics will inspire rational design of electrocatalysts for advanced Li–O2 batteries and beyond.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A conductive bimetallic MOF of NiRu-HTP is successfully prepared via ion-exchange to act as an efficient catalyst to promote oxygen redox kinetics of Li-O2 batteries. Upon discharging, O2 is preferentially chemisorbed on atomically dispersed Ru-N4 sites in NiRu-HTP, and the       d     z   2        and d xz  orbitals of Ru separately donate electrons to σ and π orbitals of O2 for its reduction to LiO2, subsequently converted into the discharge product Li2O2. Reversely, it is delithiated to LiO2 and further oxidized to O2 and Li+. NiRu-HTP displays an upshifted E d and larger adsorption strength toward LiO2 to promote the formation of film-like Li2O2 against toroid-like Li2O2 on Ni-HTP. This conduces to the charge transfer and ion diffusion across the NiRu-HTP cathode-electrolyte interface to accelerate the charge kinetics. The Li-O2 battery with NiRu-HTP displays a reduced charge/discharge polarization of 0.76 V and operates for 200 cycles without performance decay. This work regulating oxygen redox via local atomic engineering of MOFs for enhanced kinetics will inspire rational design of electrocatalysts for advanced Li-O2 batteries and beyond.

cln_elements.content:
The well-aligned nanowire arrays of Ni-HTP were grown directly on carbon paper as electrodes through the coordination of Ni2+ with 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene (HTP) in a hydrothermal reaction (Figure S1). NiRu-HTP was prepared by partially replacing Ni sites with Ru via an ion-exchange method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP electrodes are shown in a and S2, respectively. The directional nanoarrays densely surround the carbon fibers of about 30 nm in diameter and ∼1 μm in length, which induce the hierarchical porous structure to benefit electron transfer, gas diffusion, and exposure of catalytic active sites. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP nanowires manifest high crystallinity and interplanar spacing of 1.8 nm, as displayed in b and S3. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) measurement of NiRu-HTP indicates that the contents of Ru and Ni are 37 and 63%, respectively.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP in c and S4a suggest their high crystalline features. Pawley refinements were conducted to simulate their crystal structures, which reveal that they can be assigned to the hexagonal structure. The prominent peaks at 4.7, 9.4, 12.4, and 16.5° are corresponding to the (001), (002), (210), and (004) facets, respectively, indicating the long-range order within the ab plane. Their comprehensive crystallographic information is depicted in Table S1, and their main structure variations are the lattice constants and unit cell volume. The Ni or Ru atoms are coordinated with the tritopic HTP linkers to form hexagonal units in Ni-HTP or NiRu-HTP with the layered graphene-like honeycomb structure, as depicted in d and S4b. The enlarged HRTEM image of NiRu-HTP perpendicular to the c-axis in e presents an ordered honeycomb arrangement of hexagonal pores of 2.0 nm along the [001] direction, which is consistent with the simulated structure of NiRu-HTP. The molecular structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP were disclosed in Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of Figure S5. The three peaks at 1273, 1513, and 1619 cm–1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C–C, C–N, and CN bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively. The stretching vibration peak of C–N upshifts from 1502 cm–1 (H–N–C, HTP) to 1513 cm–1 (Ru/Ni–N–C) due to the formation of Ni–N or Ru–N bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, along with the peak disappearance of Ar-NH2 at 3275 cm–1.

X-ray absorption spectroscopy is employed to study the coordination of Ni and Ru in Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP. g displays the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Ni K-edge in NiO, Ni-HTP, and NiRu-HTP. The edge positions of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are approaching that of NiO, indicating that the Ni species are positively charged with the valence state of +2, in consistence with XPS (Figure S6b). The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum of Ni-HTP displays its characteristic peak at 1.3 Å, and it is assigned to the Ni–N bond (h). The EXAFS fitting indicates the average coordination number of 4 on Ni within Ni-HTP (Figure S8), corresponding to the Ni-N4 units, in line with the resolved crystal structure in Figure S4. The XANES spectra of Ru K-edge in i suggest that the edge position of NiRu-HTP is located between Ru foil and RuO2, revealing that Ru exists with the valence state between 0 and +4. The Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectrum of NiRu-HTP in j exhibits a characteristic peak of 1.47 Å for the Ru–N bond, and its fitting indicates an average coordination number of 4 for Ru–N in Figure S8. In comparison with Ru foil and RuO2, no characteristic peaks of Ru–Ru bonds in NiRu-HTP can be observed and suggest the atomically dispersed Ru sites. The wavelet transform (WT) analyses are further performed for the Ru K-edge XANES spectra of NiRu-HTP (k). It displays a WT intensity maximum at ≈5.0 Å–1 for the planar Ru–N coordination, which is obviously different from RuO2 and Ru–Ru bonds at 10.5 Å–1 in Ru foil. This verifies the atomic dispersion of Ru-N4 in NiRu-HTP.

Electronic Structure of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP

The electronic structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are uncovered by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. According to the total density of state (TDOS) analyses in a,b, the continuous electron occupation of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP near the Fermi level (E f) suggests that both possess a high electrical conductivity. The obviously larger electron density of NiRu-HTP near E f than that of Ni-HTP implies a higher electrical conductivity, which is confirmed by the conductivity measurements in Figure S9. In addition, the fully symmetric electron state densities of Ni-HTP indicate that the Ni atoms are of low spin with no single electron. In NiRu-HTP, the electron state densities near E f are asymmetric and spin-polarized, which is attributed to the plentiful single electrons on Ru atoms, contributing to the gas adsorption and activation. Generally, the d-orbital energy level center (E d) is considered as a good descriptor to evaluate the adsorbate-metal interaction and electrocatalytic activity. The integration of TDOS of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP yields the E d of −1.82 and −1.43 eV for Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP, respectively. The higher E d of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP suggests the enhanced O2 adsorption and higher oxygen reduction activity. The valence band maxima (E VB) of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are estimated to be ca. −0.32 and 0.07 eV, respectively (Figure S10). Since the valence electrons are approaching E f and mainly contribute to the d states, it allows the distinctly higher d-orbital energy level of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP, in accordance with the abovementioned TDOS analyses.

PDOS calculations are performed to investigate the interplay between Ni-HTP/NiRu-HTP and O2 molecules, as plotted in c,d. The electronic interaction is regarded as the coupling of molecular orbitals of O2 with d orbitals of metal nodes, giving rise to the orbital splitting to form the separated bonding and antibonding orbitals in Figure S11. The bonding states locate far below the E f and are generally fully filled, while the electron filling of antibonding states is decided by the position of d-orbitals relative to E f and contributes to the bonding strength. Obviously, NiRu-HTP manifests a significantly higher E d and larger hybridization degree with the 2p orbitals of O2 than Ni-HTP, which implies its higher bonding strength with O2. Specifically, at the Ni-N4 site, the d xz and d yz orbitals of Ni are overlapped with π orbitals of O2 to generate the (d xz /d yz -π)* orbitals, as shown in c. For the Ru-N4 site, the d z 2 and d xz orbitals of the Ru site are coupled with the σ and π orbitals of O2 to constitute the respective ( d z 2 -σ)* and (d xz -π)* orbitals, as plotted in d. As compared with the (d xz /d yz -π)* in Ni-HTP, the ( d z 2 -σ)* and (d xz -π)* in NiRu-HTP displays a lower electron occupancy and higher energy level, which suggest the enhanced O2 adsorption and boosted Ru–O2 interaction. The O2-enrichment capabilities of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are confirmed by low-pressure O2 adsorption at 298.25 K (Figure S12). Their O2 uptake linearly rises as a function of pressure, and NiRu-HTP exhibits an O2 adsorption of 7.02 cm–3 g–1 under an ambient atmosphere, obviously outperforming Ni-HTP (3.33 cm–3 g–1), suggesting the stronger O2 adsorption on NiRu-HTP.

The molecular structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP were disclosed in Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of Figure S5. The three peaks at 1273, 1513, and 1619 cm-1 are ascribed to the stretching vibrations of C-C, C-N, and CN bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively. The stretching vibration peak of C-N upshifts from 1502 cm-1 (H-N-C, HTP) to 1513 cm-1 (Ru/Ni-N-C) due to the formation of Ni-N or Ru-N bonds in NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, along with the peak disappearance of Ar-NH2 at 3275 cm-1.

X-ray absorption spectroscopy is employed to study the coordination of Ni and Ru in Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP. g displays the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Ni K-edge in NiO, Ni-HTP, and NiRu-HTP. The edge positions of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are approaching that of NiO, indicating that the Ni species are positively charged with the valence state of +2, in consistence with XPS (Figure S6b). The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum of Ni-HTP displays its characteristic peak at 1.3 Å, and it is assigned to the Ni-N bond (h). The EXAFS fitting indicates the average coordination number of 4 on Ni within Ni-HTP (Figure S8), corresponding to the Ni-N4 units, in line with the resolved crystal structure in Figure S4. The XANES spectra of Ru K-edge in i suggest that the edge position of NiRu-HTP is located between Ru foil and RuO2, revealing that Ru exists with the valence state between 0 and +4. The Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectrum of NiRu-HTP in j exhibits a characteristic peak of 1.47 Å for the Ru-N bond, and its fitting indicates an average coordination number of 4 for Ru-N in Figure S8. In comparison with Ru foil and RuO2, no characteristic peaks of Ru-Ru bonds in NiRu-HTP can be observed and suggest the atomically dispersed Ru sites. The wavelet transform (WT) analyses are further performed for the Ru K-edge XANES spectra of NiRu-HTP (k). It displays a WT intensity maximum at ~5.0 Å-1 for the planar Ru-N coordination, which is obviously different from RuO2 and Ru-Ru bonds at 10.5 Å-1 in Ru foil. This verifies the atomic dispersion of Ru-N4 in NiRu-HTP.

Electronic Structure of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP

The electronic structures of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are uncovered by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations. According to the total density of state (TDOS) analyses in a,b, the continuous electron occupation of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP near the Fermi level (E f) suggests that both possess a high electrical conductivity. The obviously larger electron density of NiRu-HTP near E f than that of Ni-HTP implies a higher electrical conductivity, which is confirmed by the conductivity measurements in Figure S9. In addition, the fully symmetric electron state densities of Ni-HTP indicate that the Ni atoms are of low spin with no single electron. In NiRu-HTP, the electron state densities near E f are asymmetric and spin-polarized, which is attributed to the plentiful single electrons on Ru atoms, contributing to the gas adsorption and activation. Generally, the d-orbital energy level center (E d) is considered as a good descriptor to evaluate the adsorbate-metal interaction and electrocatalytic activity. The integration of TDOS of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP yields the E d of -1.82 and -1.43 eV for Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP, respectively. The higher E d of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP suggests the enhanced O2 adsorption and higher oxygen reduction activity. The valence band maxima (E VB) of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP are estimated to be ca. -0.32 and 0.07 eV, respectively (Figure S10). Since the valence electrons are approaching E f and mainly contribute to the d states, it allows the distinctly higher d-orbital energy level of NiRu-HTP than that of Ni-HTP, in accordance with the abovementioned TDOS analyses.

PDOS calculations are performed to investigate the interplay between Ni-HTP/NiRu-HTP and O2 molecules, as plotted in c,d. The electronic interaction is regarded as the coupling of molecular orbitals of O2 with d orbitals of metal nodes, giving rise to the orbital splitting to form the separated bonding and antibonding orbitals in Figure S11. The bonding states locate far below the E f and are generally fully filled, while the electron filling of antibonding states is decided by the position of d-orbitals relative to E f and contributes to the bonding strength. Obviously, NiRu-HTP manifests a significantly higher E d and larger hybridization degree with the 2p orbitals of O2 than Ni-HTP, which implies its higher bonding strength with O2. Specifically, at the Ni-N4 site, the d xz  and d yz  orbitals of Ni are overlapped with π orbitals of O2 to generate the (d xz /d yz -π)* orbitals, as shown in c. For the Ru-N4 site, the       d     z   2        and d xz  orbitals of the Ru site are coupled with the σ and π orbitals of O2 to constitute the respective (      d     z   2       -σ)* and (d xz -π)* orbitals, as plotted in d. As compared with the (d xz /d yz -π)* in Ni-HTP, the (      d     z   2       -σ)* and (d xz -π)* in NiRu-HTP displays a lower electron occupancy and higher energy level, which suggest the enhanced O2 adsorption and boosted Ru-O2 interaction. The O2-enrichment capabilities of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP are confirmed by low-pressure O2 adsorption at 298.25 K (Figure S12). Their O2 uptake linearly rises as a function of pressure, and NiRu-HTP exhibits an O2 adsorption of 7.02 cm-3 g-1 under an ambient atmosphere, obviously outperforming Ni-HTP (3.33 cm-3 g-1), suggesting the stronger O2 adsorption on NiRu-HTP.

cln_elements.content:
e,f shows the differential charge density of O2 adsorption on Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP. The higher adsorption energy of O2 on NiRu-HTP (−1.47 eV) than that of Ni-HTP (0.28 eV) indicates its stronger affinity with O2. The Ru–O and Ni–O bond lengths after O2 adsorption are ca. 1.80 and 2.98 Å, respectively, suggesting the chemisorption and physical adsorption of O2 on NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively. Bader charge analyses reveal that 0.47 e– transfers from NiRu-HTP to O2 against 0.22 e– from Ni-HTP to O2, which suggest the enhanced electron transfer and higher catalytic activity on NiRu-HTP. After the injection of valence electrons into molecular orbitals of O2, the O–O bonding is weakened to manifest the elongated bond length of 1.30 and 1.27 Å for NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP, respectively, indicating the more efficient O2 activation on NiRu-HTP.

Electrochemical Performance and Mechanistic Analyses

a displays the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with voltages ranging from 2.0 to 4.0 V. In the cathodic sweep, they present successive reduction peaks, indicating the continuous generation of LiO2 and Li2O2. During the reverse sweep, two distinct oxidation peaks are ascribed to the stepwise oxidation of Li2O2 with the LiO2 intermediate. Compared with Ni-HTP, NiRu-HTP shows the larger current density, as well as larger ORR onset potential (∼2.76 V) and smaller OER onset potential (∼2.98 V), suggesting its better electrocatalytic activity. The electrochemical performance of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes in b is examined at 500 mA g–1. The total polarizations during charge/discharge of Ni-HTP are 3.98/2.67 V with a low energy efficiency of 67.1%. In contrast, NiRu-HTP presents the discharge and charge voltages of 2.74 and 3.62 V, respectively, suggesting an overvoltage of 0.88 V and energy efficiency of 75.7%. c shows the charge/discharge curves of NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP with a limited voltage of 2.20 V. NiRu-HTP and Ni-HTP cathodes show the respective ultrahigh capacities of 15,080 and 18,280 mA h g–1, which are attributed to their hierarchically porous structures and superior electrical conductivity. Meanwhile, NiRu-HTP displays a much smaller charge/discharge polarization (∼1.20 V) than Ni-HTP, indicating the enhanced ORR and OER kinetics on NiRu-HTP for the Li2O2 formation and decomposition.

d,e depicts the rate capability of Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP cathodes at the different current densities. The charge/discharge overvoltages are 0.76, 0.90, and 1.03 V for the NiRu-HTP cathode at 200, 500, and 1000 mA g–1, respectively. This is in contrast to the rapidly increased voltage hysterisis of Ni-HTP at the identical testing condition in e. f shows the plot of the overvoltages of NiRu-HTP and the other MOF-based cathodes at 200 mA g–1. Notably, NiRu-HTP presents the lowest overvoltage and is approaching the benchmarking RuO2. Their cycling performance is examined at 500 mA g–1 and presented in g. NiRu-HTP can sustain for 200 cycles with no obvious voltage drops, suggesting excellent cycling stability, while Ni-HTP operates for 150 cycles, followed by rapid voltage increase to 4.2 V. NiRu-HTP has no redox activity as indicated in Figure S13, and its superior electrochemical performance is favored by the superior catalytic activity for ORR and OER and high electrical conductivity.

The O2 consumption and generation during discharge and charge of NiRu-HTP are quantitatively analyzed with differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS). The charge-to-O2 ratios are 2.06 and 2.03 e–/O2 during discharge and charge in Figure S15, respectively, suggesting an approximate two-electron reaction for Li2O2 formation and decomposition without detectable CO2. The discharged and charged NiRu-HTP after 50 cycles were analyzed by XPS, as shown in Figure S16, revealing the main discharge product of Li2O2 with minor Li2CO3. Simultaneously, the cycled NiRu-HTP is confirmed to be highly stable with XPS and FTIR analyses in Figures S17 and S18, respectively, in agreement with no metal loss of Ni or Ru during cycles as revealed by ICP-MS of the separators extracted from Li–O2 batteries (Table S3).

The evolution of morphologies of the discharge products on Ni-HTP and NiRu-HTP is recorded with SEM at varied cutoff capacities in d,e and S19. At the capacity of 1 A h g–1, toroidal Li2O2 particulates of ca. 0.5 μm in size are grown in the interspace of Ni-HTP nanowire arrays. As the capacity changes to 2 and 5 A h g–1, more toroidal Li2O2 is accumulated to fully cover the electrode surface of Ni-HTP. However, on NiRu-HTP, Li2O2 presents a unique film-like morphology among the nanowires with a limited capacity of 1 A h g–1. When the capacity increases to 2 and 5 A h g–1, the film-like Li2O2 is gradually thickened to fill the void interspace of NiRu-HTP nanowire arrays. A similar morphology is well retained at the fully discharged NiRu-HTP in Figure S20. This contributes to the facile charge transfer and ion diffusion across the NiRu-HTP cathode/electrolyte interface, as verified by EIS in Figure S21 and Table S4, which favors the oxidative decomposition of Li2O2 in Figure S22 with reduced overvoltages. These suggest tunable kinetic behaviors of Li2O2 formation and oxidation, consistent with the battery performance in .
